intro: Merendera badghyi, commonly known as the Persian bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, violet-blue flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and has hairy, lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a hardy perennial in suitable climates. Its ornamental value has led to its cultivation in gardens, though it is not widely known outside of its native range.
